title: An Efficient GPU-based Implementation for Noise Robust Sound Source Localization
author: Zirui Lin (Tokyo Institute of Technology), Masayuki Takigahira (Honda Research Institute Japan), Naoya Terakado (Honda Research Institute Japan), Haris Gulzar (NTT Software Innovation Center), Monikka Roslianna Busto (NTT Software Innovation Center), Takeharu Eda (NTT Software Innovation Center), Katsutoshi Itoyama (Tokyo Institute of Technology), ..., Hideharu Amano (Keio University)
relevance_why: This research presents a GPU-based implementation of Sound Source Localization (SSL), relevant for audio processing systems where real-time processing is critical, aligning with my focus on audio generation and processing techniques.
background: Sound Source Localization aims to determine the origin of audio signals captured by a microphone array, which is crucial for improving auditory perception in robotic systems.
contribution: This paper introduces a GPU-accelerated implementation of a noise-robust algorithm, GSVD-MUSIC, to enhance performance for large-scale microphone arrays, achieving significant speedups.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Traditional CPU-based implementations for SSL face significant time and computational costs, especially with larger arrays, limiting real-time operation.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work leverages Generalized Singular Value Decomposition-based Multiple Signal Classification (GSVD-MUSIC) on GPUs, achieving processing speed improvements of up to 4645.1×.

key_innovation: It effectively utilizes GPU parallel processing to handle complex matrix calculations necessary for noise-robust sound source localization, enabling real-time application.
real_world_impact: Enhancing real-time sound localization could greatly benefit applications like drone navigation and human-robot interactions, providing more efficient auditory processing capabilities.
limitations: The implementation currently does not support stream processing, which may affect its responsiveness in dynamic environments.

new_terms.Generalized Singular Value Decomposition: **Generalized Singular Value Decomposition (GSVD)** is a mathematical technique used for separating signal and noise components in matrices, enhancing robustness against noise in sound localization.

open_sourcing: The implementation is built within the HARK platform, which is an open-source software suite for robot audition.
